instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no microphone
threads.message:
Hi guys, I have an 3476 that we repaired before <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> shorted, a little hole in the board. We wrired a new <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and Mac worked fine. Customer returned now with Mic not working. We tried another Mic from another Mac, same it shows no activity. I checked the lines 1,2,4 on J6601 but no short circuit here. What can I check more?

Forgot to mention, the Mic is recognized in the settings, audio also working fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no microphone
threads.message:
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> at J6601?
Did you try your test USB OSX?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no microphone
threads.message:
3.33v at J6601.
You mean Apple ASD test? I did ran a test from external USB drive if thats what you mean, same issue. It was high sierra though, I read some people have issues with that OS and the mic?

<RESISTOR>R6332</RESISTOR> = 75 ohm

Edit: not working in all OS. Ordered a brand new mic to make sure im using a good one, will report back
